Just wanted to share this LinkedIn <https://www.linkedin.com/posts/faseeh-ur-rehman-494938156_john-mueller-hi-john-is-there-an-ideal-content-activity-7252928985100148736-eYbL?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop|question that was asked> to Google's John Mueller. <https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7252928985100148736?commentUrn=urn%3Ali%3Acomment%3A%28activity%3A7252928985100148736%2C7252930953600208896%29&replyUrn=urn%3Ali%3Acomment%3A%28activity%3A7252928985100148736%2C7253131429285441537%29&dashCommentUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_comment%3A%287252930953600208896%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7252928985100148736%29&dashReplyUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_comment%3A%287253131429285441537%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7252928985100148736%29|Especially this response> to "ideal content length with respect to ranking better".

> If you count the words in best seller books, average the count, and then write the same number of words in your own book, will it become a best seller? If you make a phone that has the same dimensions as a popular smartphone, will you sell as many as they do? I love spreadsheets, but numbers aren't everything.
I found this to be a really nice way of explaining content length and ranking. The question sparked a very interesting conversation.
One thing to keep in mind is also to think  about the search intent. Sometimes the intent prohibits a long answer, sometimes a thorough in-dept piece is needed.
